data.title: Did Stalin put a hit on John Wayne?

data.text:
Rate this for plausibility:

During the waning years of his dictatorship Stalin allegedly decided to send agents to assassinate John Wayne, then a symbol of American culture. In an era when many of the biggest names in the industry were card-carrying communists or had Soviet sympathies, Wayne stood out as an outspoken anti-Communist.

Stalin was a major movie buff (like Hitler) and a particular fan of Westerns. During a night of movies in his private screening room with his vodka-drenched comrades, he decided to put a hit on Wayne. His whims could be fatal and it seems the KGB did indeed try to carry out the Vozhd's order, sending several English-speaking agents to the US,.

Somehow, the plot reached Wayne and his entourage via Western agents. When one of his friends advised him to be more cautious, the Duke declared "no ....... Commie's gonna frighten me." Apparently one of his stuntmen foiled an attempt on his life with the help of Wayne. Later, two KGB agents disguised as FBI broke into his office but several G-men were waiting for them and disarmed them. The Soviets, terrified of Stalin, begged them not to send them back to Russia. They proposed exchanging valuable intel for American citizenship. The FBI agreed.

In 1959, Nikita Khrushchev visited the United States, his plane landing in Los Angeles. He had two wishes, to visit Disneyland and meet John Wayne. The first wish was denied due to security concerns however he was invited to a glitzy, star-filled luncheon that included Elizabeth Taylor and Edward G.Robinson. And Wayne who asked Khrushchev if Stalin had really sent hitmen to kill him. The Russian responded: "That was the decision of Stalin in his last mad years. I rescinded the order."
